subject: Re: [junit] How do I make Unit Testing practical?
msgSnippet: ... Retrofitting unit tests to existing code is certainly more difficult than writing tests before writing the code (as TDD suggests). ... My experience is
messageBody:
On Wed, 2003-04-02 at 09:40, Scott Palmer wrote:

> Thanks for the comments so far, they have been reassuring.. but of
> course that was expected from this group ;-)
>
> more questions:
> Is unit testing much harder if I don't use TDD?
>

Retrofitting unit tests to existing code is certainly more difficult
than writing tests before writing the code (as TDD suggests).

> I've got a lot of code written already and retrofitting the test cases
> is going to be fun. Also, what is done about the 'bloat' that is added
> to classes by test code? (mainly when inner classes are used to
> facilitate testing). I don't care about it in the development
> environment, but if my application is to be downloaded and there are
> megabytes of embedded test code it can become an issue. (So far my
> code is a small fraction of the download, so this isn't an issue - yet)

My experience is that when I get serious about testing existing code, I
find myself redesigning existing pieces to make them more easily
testable. I end up with a lot more classes, most of which are more
focused on their intent than the original. A great side-effect is that I
am finding myself with a lot of reusable code that I did not know I had.
I am not sure because I have not run any statistics, but I think my
total number of lines of code generally decreases during this process.

>
> Another comment:
> I've been trying to get started with the unit testing and have been
> encouraging other's in my company to try it too, but I can't get any
> buy-in. I'm finding it difficult to get started so I don't really have
> a convincing argument for it other than "I've read that it is a great
> thing" :), obviously if I can make it work for me it would help. It's
> good to hear that others have had the same issues and have gotten past
> them. The examples make it look so simple and easy...

Been there, done that. Most developers don't want to write tests because
they think testing is boring or has no value added to them (i.e. it does
not help them write code better or faster). I was in that camp for quite
a while. However, when I found myself writing acceptance tests and
having them find bugs that should have been found earlier in the
development cycle, I began to look for a 'better way'. For me, using
JUnit as an integral part of my software development process does allow
me to write code that I am much more confident in. The examples do make
it look simple and easy. In practice I find it pretty simple and easy to
write tests, after the initial learning curve. I am by no means an
expert, having started doing serious work with JUnit just a couple of
months ago. But the more I use it the better I like it.


>
> On Wednesday, April 2, 2003, at 12:46 AM, Levi Cook
> <levicook@...> wrote:
> > On Tuesday, April 1, 2003, at 02:07 PM, swpalmer2001 wrote:
> >
> >> Or is this unit testing just a passing fad that is
> >> really nothing more than a bunch of hype?
> >
> > PS> Despite your opening disclaimer this sounds a little like trolling
> > :)
> >
> Yes, it does (sorry).. My intention was to get a feel for how many
> people out there have been down this road and concluded that it wasn't
> all that it was promised to be. (Not that I would find many of those
> people on this list. But maybe I could find others that were
> struggling.) I've heard the 'pros' and they are quite convincing, I
> was after the 'cons'.
>
>
